regulation.title: UK General Data Protection Regulation / Data Protection Act 2018

obligations.actionText: Must provide the identity and contact details of the controller and, where applicable, the data protection officer at the time personal data is collected
obligations.objectText: The controller's identity, contact details, and data protection officer contact details
obligations.conditionText: Where personal data is collected directly from the data subject
obligations.summary: When collecting personal data from customers, firms must state who the data controller is (the firm's legal name and registered address), how to contact the firm about data protection matters, and the contact details of the Data Protection Officer if one has been appointed.

clauseTemplate.title: Data Controller Identity
clauseTemplate.templateText: [Firm Name] (registered at [address]) is the data controller for the personal information you provide to us. If you have any questions about how we use your data, you can contact our Data Protection Officer at [email/address].
clauseTemplate.guidance: This information must be provided at the point of data collection. In financial services, it should appear prominently in the privacy notice or data protection section of the T&Cs.

obligations.actionText: Must state the purposes of processing and the legal basis relied upon for each purpose
obligations.objectText: The specific purposes for which personal data will be processed and the corresponding lawful basis under Article 6(1)
obligations.conditionText: At the time personal data is collected from the data subject
obligations.summary: Firms must clearly state why they are processing customer personal data and the legal basis for each purpose. Common lawful bases in financial services include: contractual necessity (Art 6(1)(b)) for account management, legal obligation (Art 6(1)(c)) for AML/KYC checks, and legitimate interests (Art 6(1)(f)) for fraud prevention.

clauseTemplate.title: Purposes and Lawful Basis for Processing
clauseTemplate.templateText: We process your personal data for the following purposes: (a) to provide and manage your [product/service] (legal basis: performance of our contract with you); (b) to comply with our legal and regulatory obligations including anti-money laundering checks (legal basis: legal obligation); (c) to detect and prevent fraud (legal basis: our legitimate interests in protecting our business and customers); (d) to contact you about products and services that may be of interest (legal basis: consent, where given).
clauseTemplate.guidance: Each purpose must be paired with a specific lawful basis. Firms should avoid blanket statements like 'for our business purposes'. The ICO expects granular disclosure.

obligations.actionText: Must specify the legitimate interests pursued where processing is based on Article 6(1)(f)
obligations.objectText: The specific legitimate interests of the controller or third party that form the basis for processing
obligations.conditionText: Where the lawful basis for processing is legitimate interests
obligations.summary: Where firms rely on legitimate interests as the lawful basis for processing, they must specify what those interests are. In financial services, common legitimate interests include fraud prevention, credit risk assessment, internal audit, network and information security, and direct marketing to existing customers.

clauseTemplate.title: Legitimate Interests Statement
clauseTemplate.templateText: Where we process your data based on our legitimate interests, these include: preventing fraud and financial crime; assessing credit and insurance risk; ensuring the security of our systems and services; improving our products and services; and complying with industry codes and guidance.
clauseTemplate.guidance: The ICO requires firms to be specific about their legitimate interests rather than using vague language. A legitimate interests assessment (LIA) should support each stated interest.

obligations.actionText: Must disclose the recipients or categories of recipients of personal data
obligations.objectText: The identity or categories of third parties who will receive the customer's personal data
obligations.conditionText: At the time of data collection, covering all planned data sharing
obligations.summary: Firms must tell customers who their personal data will be shared with. In financial services, this typically includes credit reference agencies, fraud prevention agencies (e.g. CIFAS), insurers and reinsurers, regulatory bodies (FCA, ICO), law enforcement, and third-party service providers.

clauseTemplate.title: Data Recipients and Sharing
clauseTemplate.templateText: We may share your personal data with: credit reference agencies; fraud prevention agencies; our regulators (including the FCA and ICO); law enforcement agencies where required; third-party service providers who help us operate our business; and other companies in our group. Full details of these recipients are available in our Privacy Notice.
clauseTemplate.guidance: Financial services firms have extensive data-sharing obligations. The disclosure should cover all regular data flows, not just those that require consent.

obligations.actionText: Must state the period for which personal data will be stored, or the criteria used to determine that period
obligations.objectText: Data retention periods or the criteria for determining how long personal data is kept
obligations.conditionText: At the time of data collection
obligations.summary: Firms must tell customers how long their personal data will be kept. Financial services firms typically retain data for at least 6 years after the end of the customer relationship (to meet FCA record-keeping requirements and limitation periods), though some categories of data may be retained longer for anti-money laundering purposes.

clauseTemplate.title: Data Retention Periods
clauseTemplate.templateText: We will retain your personal data for as long as your account is active and for a minimum of [6/7] years after the end of our relationship, in order to comply with our regulatory obligations. Some data may be retained for longer where required for anti-money laundering or fraud prevention purposes, or where we need to resolve any ongoing disputes.
clauseTemplate.guidance: The ICO expects specific retention periods rather than vague statements. Financial services firms should align retention with FCA SYSC record-keeping rules and Limitation Act periods.

obligations.actionText: Must inform data subjects of their rights including access, rectification, erasure, restriction, objection and data portability
obligations.objectText: The full set of data subject rights available under UK GDPR Articles 15-22
obligations.conditionText: At the time of data collection
obligations.summary: Firms must tell customers about their data protection rights: the right to access their data, have it corrected, request deletion, restrict processing, object to processing, and obtain their data in a portable format. Firms must also explain how to exercise these rights.

clauseTemplate.title: Your Data Protection Rights
clauseTemplate.templateText: Under data protection law, you have the right to: access the personal data we hold about you; have inaccurate data corrected; request deletion of your data (in certain circumstances); restrict our processing of your data; object to our processing (including for direct marketing); and receive your data in a portable format. To exercise any of these rights, please contact us at [contact details].
clauseTemplate.guidance: Rights must be listed individually with brief explanations. The right to erasure and right to object have limitations in financial services (e.g. cannot delete data needed for regulatory compliance).

obligations.actionText: Must inform data subjects of their right to withdraw consent at any time where consent is the lawful basis
obligations.objectText: The right to withdraw consent and the fact that withdrawal does not affect the lawfulness of processing before withdrawal
obligations.conditionText: Where processing is based on consent under Article 6(1)(a) or Article 9(2)(a)
obligations.summary: Where firms rely on consent as the lawful basis for processing (commonly used for marketing communications and sharing data with third parties for their marketing), customers must be told they can withdraw consent at any time. Withdrawal must be as easy as giving consent.

clauseTemplate.title: Right to Withdraw Consent
clauseTemplate.templateText: Where we process your data based on your consent (for example, for marketing communications), you have the right to withdraw your consent at any time. You can do this by contacting us at [contact details] or using the unsubscribe link in any marketing email. Withdrawing consent will not affect the lawfulness of any processing carried out before you withdrew.
clauseTemplate.guidance: This is only required where consent is actually relied upon. Most financial services data processing uses contractual necessity or legitimate interests, but marketing consent is very common.

obligations.actionText: Must inform data subjects of their right to lodge a complaint with the Information Commissioner's Office
obligations.objectText: The right to complain to the ICO as the supervisory authority and how to contact the ICO
obligations.conditionText: At the time of data collection
obligations.summary: Customers must be told they have the right to complain to the ICO if they are unhappy with how their personal data is handled. The ICO's contact details must be provided or the customer must be directed to ico.org.uk.

clauseTemplate.title: Right to Complain to the ICO
clauseTemplate.templateText: If you are unhappy with how we have handled your personal data, you have the right to lodge a complaint with the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO). You can contact the ICO at: Information Commissioner's Office, Wycliffe House, Water Lane, Wilmslow, Cheshire SK9 5AF, or visit ico.org.uk.
clauseTemplate.guidance: The ICO complaint right must be clearly stated alongside the firm's own complaint process. Firms should not discourage customers from escalating to the ICO.

obligations.actionText: Must inform data subjects where personal data is transferred to a third country and the safeguards in place
obligations.objectText: Details of any international data transfers and the adequacy decisions or appropriate safeguards relied upon
obligations.conditionText: Where personal data is transferred outside the UK
obligations.summary: Where customer data is transferred outside the UK, firms must disclose this and explain what safeguards are in place. Safeguards may include UK adequacy regulations, standard contractual clauses, or binding corporate rules. This is increasingly relevant as financial services firms use cloud providers and offshore processing centres.

clauseTemplate.title: International Data Transfers
clauseTemplate.templateText: We may transfer your personal data outside the UK where necessary for the provision of our services. Where we do, we ensure appropriate safeguards are in place, such as the use of standard contractual clauses approved by the ICO, or transfers to countries that have been assessed as providing an adequate level of data protection.
clauseTemplate.guidance: Many financial services firms transfer data internationally (e.g. to group companies, cloud providers, offshore processing centres). The specific countries and safeguards should be stated.

obligations.actionText: Must state whether providing personal data is a statutory or contractual requirement and the consequences of not providing it
obligations.objectText: Whether data provision is obligatory or voluntary, and what happens if the customer does not provide data
obligations.conditionText: At the time of data collection
obligations.summary: Firms must tell customers whether providing their personal data is mandatory (e.g. for AML identity verification) or optional, and what happens if they refuse. In financial services, refusing to provide identity data will typically mean the firm cannot open an account or provide the product.

clauseTemplate.title: Consequences of Not Providing Data
clauseTemplate.templateText: Some of the personal data we ask for is required by law (for example, to verify your identity for anti-money laundering purposes) or is necessary for us to provide our services to you. If you do not provide this data, we may be unable to open your account or continue to provide our services. We will always tell you which information is mandatory and which is optional.
clauseTemplate.guidance: Financial services firms have legal obligations to collect certain data (AML/KYC). The distinction between mandatory and optional data collection should be clear.

obligations.actionText: Must inform data subjects about the existence of automated decision-making including profiling that produces legal or similarly significant effects, and provide meaningful information about the logic involved
obligations.objectText: Automated decision-making processes, the logic involved, and the significance and envisaged consequences for the data subject
obligations.conditionText: Where automated individual decision-making including profiling takes place with legal or similarly significant effects
obligations.summary: Where firms use automated systems to make decisions that significantly affect customers (e.g. credit scoring, automated insurance pricing, fraud detection), they must disclose this, explain the logic involved in meaningful terms, and describe the significance and likely consequences of the processing.

obligations.actionText: Must implement suitable safeguards including the right to obtain human intervention, express a point of view and contest automated decisions
obligations.objectText: The right to human review of automated decisions, the right to express a viewpoint, and the right to challenge the outcome
obligations.conditionText: Where automated decisions with legal or significant effects are made under Article 22(2) exceptions
obligations.summary: Where firms make automated decisions that significantly affect customers, they must provide safeguards including the ability to request human review, express a point of view, and contest the decision. This is particularly relevant for automated credit decisions, insurance pricing, and fraud-related account blocks.

obligations.actionText: Must ensure that consent is freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous, obtained through a clear affirmative action, and distinguishable from other matters
obligations.objectText: The form and presentation of consent requests within customer agreements and communications
obligations.conditionText: Where consent is relied upon as the lawful basis for processing
obligations.summary: Where firms rely on consent for data processing (e.g. marketing, third-party data sharing), the consent must be freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous. Consent must not be bundled into general T&Cs. Pre-ticked boxes, silence, or inactivity do not constitute valid consent.

obligations.actionText: Must provide all data protection information in a concise, transparent, intelligible and easily accessible form, using clear and plain language
obligations.objectText: All information provided under Articles 13 and 14, including privacy notices and data protection sections of terms and conditions
obligations.conditionText: When providing any information about data processing to data subjects
obligations.summary: All data protection information must be concise, transparent, intelligible and easily accessible, using clear and plain language. Privacy notices should not be buried in lengthy T&Cs. Where information is addressed to a child, it must be adapted accordingly.
